title: bute meets ayrshire in memory of calum
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAn Argyll and Bute charity has joined forces with the Prince#s Foundation to offer families living with cancer short getaways at a five-star, self-catering cottage at Dumfries House estate, East Ayrshire.Caroline Speirs co-founded Calum#s Cabin with her husband Duncan and daughter Jenna to provide holiday homes on the Isle of Bute for children suffering from cancer or a cancer-related disease. Caroline and Duncan were parents to Calum, who sadly passed away aged  after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Knowing he and his family lived in a beautul part of the world, Calum wanted children suffering from cancer to come to Bute for special getaways where the entire family could cherish quality time together and recharge their batteries for what may lie ahead.The charity now runs several holiday homes on Bute and private flats in Glasgow for families travelling to the city for treatments at the Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Care and Royal Hospital for Children.Dumfries House Lodge is a -room, five-star country guest house with two self-catering cottages, all staffed round the clock.Eight families have been referred through the children#s charity so far to enjoy a four-night stay free of charge.Caroline said: #To allow Calum#s Cabin families to be helped in such a special way is an absolute honour. For many of the families who have had this opportunity, their conditions would have been too severe to get away on holiday, or to come to Bute, so Dumfries House is perfect. Sadly for some, it has been their final holiday together.#The families have been blown away by their stays at Dumfries House. The peace and tranquility of the estate make it an ideal getaway and the staff could not have done more. Our families have come away from each break with unforgettable memories and a renewed energy and focus for whatever may come next.#Louis MacCallum, director of commercial for the Prince#s Foundation at Dumfries House, said: #Anyone who has met Caroline and Duncan cannot fail to be inspired into helping their charity in any way they can. Being a Buteman myself, I was already aware of the wonderful work of Calum#s Cabin on Bute and in Glasgow and was delighted to help.#

title: melrose-sevens-bosses-make-u-turn-road-closure
story: BOSSES at Melrose Rugby have made a U-turn on their plans to close off St Marys Road during next years sevens.As previously reported, the stretch was due to be shut for two weeks ndash to allow for a temporary stand to be erected.But following discussions with the towns community council, chiefs running the four-day tournament have changed their minds.Now St Marys road will only be partially closed on game days, with a traffic light system in place.Philip Morris, sevens tournament director at Melrose Rugby, said: ldquoAn event like this one will of course come with an element of disruption to the usual routine."The Melrose community has embraced the sevens every year, however, concerns around an expanded event are of course completely understandable."For the avoidance of doubt, wersquore working really hard to support local businesses as suppliers to the event."And wersquoll also be consulting with local residents to address any specic concerns they have too."We are confident the economic boost to Melrose and the surrounding Borders towns during the expanded sevens event will be huge."News of the U-turn has been welcomed by members of Melrose Community Council.Chairman William Windram said: "I still think the plans are a bit fluid at the moment, and I think there is still a lot of work going on behind the scenes."There are, however, still some issues like late night noise that have not been considered yet, but we have asked them [the club] to come back to our meeting in February to give us an update."Some amelioration has certainly taken place and we should be pleased."One of the concerns raised by Melrose Community Council at its November meeting was the impact the tournament would have on churchgoers ndash with the event taking place over the Easter weekend.In response, Mr Morris said: "We are working hard to ensure the important Easter Sunday church service is not impacted and people will be able to get to and from the church without signicant disruption."Now the traffic situation on St Marys Road is becoming clearer, we have a plan that we feel will satisfy our local residents. We look forward to sharing this plan with the local Minister and her congregation in the coming weeks."We would like to take this opportunity to thank the Melrose Community Council, local residents, and businesses for all their amazing support. We look forward to putting on a brilliant event in  and continuing to support the local and wider Borders community in the coming years."

title: borderline-funding-withdrawal-nothing-short-disgrace
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council and NHS Borders have been criticised for cutting funding to the Borderline mental health service.As we revealed last week the Galashiels-based service will be left without funding during .Since being set up in , Borderline has handled more than , calls, despite the phone lines only being open from pm till pm each night.However, NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council has withdrawn funding from the service, saying that other alternative options are available.At a meeting of Scottish Borders Council on Thursday Kelso councillor Euan Robson, who represented Roxburgh and Berwickshire at Holyrood between  and , asked the local authorityrsquos ruling executive: ldquoWho took the decision to terminate the funding for Borderline Helpline and for what reasons, and is any replacement service being set up Fellow Kelso councillor Tom Weatherston, who acts as the ruling executiversquos member for adult social care, replied: ldquoThe decision to stop funding Borderline was jointly taken by NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council, at the executive management team meeting.ldquoThe health and social care joint organisation, with signicant financial pressures in mind, reviewed its funding for this organisation.ldquoConsideration was given to a quality and impact assessment, and the external review of commissioned services, including Borderline.ldquoAlthough Borderline provides a good quality service, there are now alternative national helplines, such as Breathing Space and the Samaritans, as well as the local mental health and crisis team, and so we have reached the dficult decision to end the contract with six months notice.ldquoWersquod also like to highlight the other areas of prevention services in which we have invested, such as the local area coordination team, the Wellbeing College, and the wellbeing service.ldquoIn addition, we have also been working with primary care services to provide a comprehensive primary care mental health service, which is available directly to patients from GP practices across the Scottish Borders.ldquoWe will work hard with Borderline to find alternative sources of funding, and we are working hard with them to develop a transition plan.Councillor Robson asked a follow up question, telling the chamber: ldquoI appreciate that councillor Weatherston was not particularly involved in this decision, but would he agree with me that itrsquos nothing short of a disgrace that an organisation, partly staffed by volunteers, thatrsquos handled , calls from people in vulnerable situations for  years, and is open  days a year, has its funding withdrawn without prior consultation ldquoAnd worse still, it was allegedly informed that there is no right of appeal.Would he further accept that Borderline helping people in distress at a cost of pound, per annum actually saves resources where in the health and social care system, and this decision is therefore a  economy ldquoWill he further agree that some of the alternative provision mentioned does not fill the gap that Borderline occupies ldquoAnd finally, would he, or someone , therefore convene a meeting in the new year to find a way to save this service for the Borders community To which councillor Weatherston replied: ldquoI wonrsquot use the word disgrace, Irsquoll use the word disappointment."As the chief executive has said today, we face huge financial challenges.ldquoBorderline is a great service, but there is now a -hour, seven days a week service set up and funded by the NHS.ldquoNo one is in dispute that this is a great service, but we donrsquot have the funds to keep it going, unfortunately. Wersquove looked at other options, and the options available to people in the Borders now are really good.ldquoThis service is open for three hours a night, seven days a week. The alternative service is  , so there are other alternatives.ldquoWersquore working hard with the group to source other funding, but Irsquom sorry we have no other option.

title: odd-shaped-organiser-set-sights-peebles-high-fundraiser
story: ORGANISERS of the Odd Shaped Ball are to stage a new event in February in a bid to raise thousands of pounds to support Peebles High School following the recent fire.The PHS Recovery Ball will take place on Friday, February  at Peebles Hydro with tickets going on sale in early January.The event is being supported by local musicians, the Back Green Band, who have offered to perform free of charge, while the Hydrorsquos General Manager Patrick Diack has pledged his support as a venue partner.The Odd Shaped Ball has raised more than pound, since being launched in , generating funds for the junior sections of a number of local sports clubs, including football, rugby, golf, cricket, hockey, tennis and netball, as well as funding sports equipment for Priorsford, Kingsland and Halryude Primary Schools over the past two years.Their most recent event, staged in September, generated a record pound, on the night, with fantastic support from local parents and businesses.Co-organiser Mark Thomson told us: ldquoThe whole community has been affected by the fire at Peebles High School, but the pupils and teachers have shown great resilience in overcoming many of the challenges they are facing."The Odd Shaped Ball epitomes the community spirit in Peebles and we immediately thought doing something similar in the aftermath of the fire would be a great way of showing our support, bringing people together and raising valuable funds that are needed by the school in the months ahead.ldquoItrsquos also the weekend after Valentinersquos Day so wersquore recommending that couples ditch their plans for a romantic night and come along to have a great night at the PHS Recovery Ball instead!A table of  for the event will cost pound, which will include a special  Gin ndash distilled at Peebles Hydro ndash on arrival, three-course meal, live band and other entertainment.An array of fantastic prizes will be up for grabs in the raffle and auction, with the red-carpet photographer also hand to capture the best moments.Tickets will be available via the Odd Shaped Ball Facebook page and you can register your interest now. Every penny raised will go towards the Peebles High School fund to support the departments most affected by the fire.Co-organiser Ross Duncan added: "Wersquove already been contacted by a number of people and businesses across Scotland who have offered to support the event so we want to tap into that and quickly channel it in a positive way."We hope the local community will also get behind the Ball, through buying tickets, providing sponsorship or donating a prize.ldquoThe Odd Shaped Ball has been a hugely popular sell-out event for the past six years with  people attending so we hope we can replicate that success for this event."We appreciate there are many charity events that people are asked to get behind, but we believe helping young people at Peebles High School is a very worthy cause at this time.Further updates will be made available at www.facebook OddShapedBallPeebles

title: borderers-feature-queens-new-year-honours-list
story: SEVERAL Borderers have been included in the Queens New Year Honours List.Steve Penny from the Tweed Valley Mountain Rescue Team has been awarded an MBE.The -year-old from Lindean has been a volunteer with the rescue team since moving to the area in .He also joined the Search  Rescue Dog Association Scotlandas a handler in the same year.Steve said: "I was quite shocked when I got the letter, but also very proud."It means a lot as my grandfather got an MBE in , and at this time when my father has recently died it holds a very special meaning."As well as his local roles within mountain rescue, which have included Team Leader, Assistant Leader and Secretary, Steve is also the wellbeing officer for Scottish Mountain Rescue.In , his wellbeing framework for volunteer rescue responders was rolled out across Scotland and is now forming the backbone of a wider UK Wellbeing Initiative via UK Search and Rescue.And he is also a leading trainer across the country as part of the SMR Search Working Group.Steve has also taken on a series of Executive positions within Scottish Mountain Rescue over the years - as Secretary between  and  and as vice-chair from  to .Mr Penny added: "The team has changed over the years but we have always had a good team of people."Over the years weve attended many, many incidents."One that stands out for me was when I was with my dog during an avalanche, and although it was a fatality we were still able to locate the body quickly."Receiving an OBE for services to Animal Health is Tweeddales Dr Martyn Blissitt.The Scottish Government veterinary adviser has been at the forefront of the countrys fight against disease in farming livestock.After qualying as a veterinary surgeon in , Martyn completed a PhD at Edinburgh University seven years later.He spent his early working le in Somerset and Australia before joining the State Veterinary Service in Taunton during the BSE crisis of , moving to Ayr Animal Health Office the following year.He was promoted to Veterinary Adviser to SEERAD in  and has remained an adviser with the Scottish Government, being credited with Scotland achieving official TB free status.Berwickshires Ian Davidson has also been awarded an OBE for Services to Agriculture.Mr Davidson is Head of Agriculture Policy at the Scottish Government.He has most recently been responsible for the Scottish Rural Development Programme.And has previously held posts in developing the current CAP in Scotland and also in the Area Office network as part of the RPID.

title: ryan-jenn-set-open-string-jams-23rd-year
story: THE String Jam Club opens its rd year next week with the highly-acclaimed Scottish trad duo of Ryan Young and Jenn Butterworth.Ryan leads the New Wave of traditional Scottish fiddlers, according to the BBC, bringing new and exciting ideas to the folk genre.He holds both a first class honours and a Masters degree from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, as well as being a twice a finalist in both the BBC Radio  Young Folk Awards and the BBC Scotland Young Traditional Musician of the Year.He was nominated for the Horizon Award at the  BBC Radio  Folk Awards and was the winner of Folking Best Musician for .Despite his comparatively young years, Ryan is already on his way to becoming a folk giant.And while his CV is fairly impressive, the superb guitarist who will be accompanying him at the County Hotel has just as extraordinary a background.Jenn Butterworth was Musician of the Year at the MG Alba Scots Trad Music Awards , and is one of only four musicians shortlisted for Musician of the Year Award at the prestigious BBC Radio  Folk Awards .Based in Glasgow, she is a lynchpin of the vibrant and thriving Scottish folk scene, performing regularly with a wide range of artists including her own projects, Jenn Butterworth  Laura-Beth Salter, and the fabulous Kinnaris Quintet.Jenn is a highly recognised teacher with a wide range of experience, and was recently awarded Tutor of the Year at the  Scots Trad Music Awards.She is lecturer in Practical Studies in the Traditional Music Department of the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, and a regular member of the teaching staff for Glasgow Fiddle Workshop.Ryan and Jenn were nominated as Folk Band of the Year in the Scots Trad Music Awards, and were the only UK artists to be selected to perform at the Womex Expo .String Jam promoter Allie Fox said: "They gave a simply awe-inspiring performance at String Jam Club last year and are back by popular demand."The music was exhilarating, magical, and exciting, nearly causing a riot after the first set of tunes."They got two standing ovations and three encores, and the atmosphere was so exciting that we just had to book them again. This will be an inspirational gig and an unbelievable display of exceptional trad musicianship."Tickets for Ryan Young and Jenn Butterworth at the String Jam Club on Saturday, January , priced at pound, are available online from Eventbrite, in person from the County Hotel or by phone -.Doors open at .pm for an pm start.

title: ross-tunes-hawick-music-club
story: HAWICK Music Club welcomeclassical guitarist Ross Wilson for their opening concert of .On Sunday, January , the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland graduate will perform at the Cornucopia Room.In  Ross began studying part-time at the Segovia Guitar Academy in Pordenone, Italy with Professor Paola Pegoraro, after graduating with a Masters in Scotland.Modern Spanish composers feature mostly in Rossrsquo repertoire, beginning with Frederico Mompou and his elegant Catalanonian folk inspired music.Ross has a particular interest in Baroque and early music which is reflected in his choice of composers, such as JS Bach and John Downland.He has given recitals across Britain including at the Glasgow City Halls as part of the BBC SSO Club Concert series.Ross will present a warm Mediterranean programme during his visit to Hawick on January .Tickets, priced at pound per adult with under s free, are available from Muriel Wilson on  The concert starts at .pm.

title: lamont-rolls-red-carpet-westminster-visits
story: FRESHLY re-elected MP, John Lamont, has urged locals and schools to get in touch with himthey would like to visit Westminster in .MR Lamont has welcomed hundreds of constituents and a number of schools to Westminster since he became and MP in .Borders schools making educational visits to Parliament can claim  percent of receipted travel costs, up to a maximum of pound.MPs can also secure tickets for Prime Ministerrsquos Questions and other debates and tours free of charge for constituents visiting the Parliament.The MP Berwickshire, Roxburgh  Selkirk said: ldquoI always enjoy welcoming constituents and students to Westminster.ldquoMost people only ever see the palace on their televisions or in the newspaper."However, the building has some fantastic rooms to see as well as being steeped in history.ldquoI always get great feedback from visitors saying how informative and friendly the parliamentary staff have been during their visit."Teachers also think that visiting Parliament gives their pupils a better understanding of how our political system worksldquoI would urge anyone to get in touch with me directlythey fancy seeing Westminster as part of their trip to London.Anyone interested in visiting Parliament can contact Johnrsquos office or email him at john.lamont.mp@parliament.uk.

title: newtown-set-new-enlarged-playpark
story: CHILDREN in Newtown St Boswells will have plenty to cheer about later this year as the village has moved up the playpark pecking order.Because of delays to the new Earlston Primary School development, there is outstanding cash earmarked for new play facilities.And it has now been announced that Newtown will get the new facilities later in .Scottish Borders Council convenor David Parker explained: ldquoOne of the parks which was agreed for the new financial year was Earlston, but this project cannot proceed until the new school is developed and therefore the funding resources against the project have been released.ldquoOnce we have the outcome of the tender process in Newtown, I will be able to confirm more information about timescale in terms of getting a design which we can take to the community for consultation.ldquo Around pound, will be spent on developing the playpark at Sprouston Road.As well as replacing the current swings and slides, the new enlarged park will feature more equipment to suit a wider age range of children.The move has been welcomed by local councillor Elaine Thornton-Nicol. She said: ldquoThe need for a new and extended playpark was identied a number of years ago.ldquoI want to say a huge thank you to David Parker and all the officers that have been involved in making this a very Merry Christmas for Newtown St Boswells.ldquoWe are looking forward to seeing the designs in  and working with the community to make this pound, do as much as it can for our village.Discussions have already taken place between Councillors Parker and Thornton-Nicol, as well as community council secretary Fiona MacPherson, about the need for a better and larger park to meet the needs of the villagersquos growing population.Ms MacPherson told us: ldquoEveryone will be thrilled that we are on our way to a fabulous play facility.

title: hamilton-calls-government-help-save-borders-high-streets
story: BORDERS MSP Rachael Hamilton has called on the Scottish Government to do more to tackle the decline of the high street and encourage increased local footfall in town centres.Figures show that footfall in most Borders towns has fallen signicantly over the past decade.Towns such as Galashiels and Hawick have been hit hard with shoppers either going online or to the cities.Mrs Hamilton wants the Scottish Government to help by addressing crippling business rates which has left many shops vacant.The member for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire said: "Tackling the decline of our high streets is a constant uphill battle, but with the right package of measures in place, we can reverse the trend.ldquoBusinesses wonrsquot move to an areathere isnrsquot an incentive to do so."We need to create a pro-business atmosphere on our high streets, with emphasis on local start-ups.ldquoBusiness rates relief and the alleviation of planning restrictions would ensure that there are far fewer barriers to business moving in."As well as cutting business rates, Mrs Hamilton wants a plan to support the regions high streets become dynamic, flexible, welcoming spaces, able to provide a range of dferent experiences.She believes effective BIDs are also beneficial.Mrs Hamilton added: "We need to see more incentives for local businesses to move in, expand and fill vacant premises on the high street.ldquoIn the new year, I will be continuing my work to save our high streets, and will liaise proactively with all high street businesses to forward my plans for a better high street."

title: teaching-resume-peebles-high-school-february
story: STUDENTS from Peebles High School willto the school in February after extensive works on the site were undertaken during the Christmas holiday.Since the blaze at the High School on November , students were ided between classrooms and community centres in Peebles and Galashiels for face-to-face teaching.S-S students willto Peebles High on Monday, February  after their prelim exams which finish on January .S-S students will complete school work from home on February  so staff can ensure a safe and organisedto the site. Learning materials will be provided through the Show my Homework app and Glow. Junior students will thento the High School on February .Tracey Logan, Chief Executive of Scottish Borders Council, said: ldquoWe have continued to work right up to Christmas and in the days since to put plans in place to have all pupils back at Peebles High School as soon as possible. This includes the provision of temporary classrooms in the High Schoolrsquos grounds and preparations for these are well underway.ldquoAlthough work continues, we are now fairly confident that, all going well, all pupils will be able toto Peebles High School over the two days of rd and th February. This still depends on a number of factors but with the help and support of a huge range of staff and partners, we are very optimistic that we can achieve this.ldquoWe would like to give parents and carers as much notice as possible this includes the decision to ask S-S pupils to work from home on Monday  February. The logistics of moving from the temporary sites and preparing the new arrangements are hugely challenging and the safety and well-being of pupils is our priority. As such, the operation to move from the temporary sites from Friday lunchtime over the weekend and into Monday needs to be carefully planned and managed.ldquoI am delighted that we are in such a positive position so quickly given the scale of the challenge. We will continue to work on the details around these plans and will keep pupils, parents and staff updated as we make more progress.Parts of the school which were greatly damaged after the fire will still be inaccessible to students for their safety.Teaching and travel arrangements which were in place prior to the Christmas break will remain when studentsto teaching on Monday, January .All the temporary teaching locations used by Peebles High will be given back to Live Borders on January , with the exception of the Drill Hall which will continue to be used as a back-up teaching venue.Ms Logan added: ldquoOnce again Irsquod like to pay tribute to everyone who has supported the Council and Peebles High School during this extremely challenging period, and of course to all the pupils, parents and staff for their patience during this time.ldquoThe support of our partners Live Borders and CGI, numerous contractors and the local community has been invaluable.ldquoIrsquod also like to publicly thank all my staff who have worked so hard since  November to get us to this position.Leader of Scottish Borders Council, councillor Shona Haslam said: ldquoI would like to again thank the officers, staff and pupils for their work in getting us to this stage."To have all the pupils back on one site only weeks after the devastating fire is an amazing achievement."We will continue to work on a longer term solution with partners to ensure that we continue to provide the best quality education to our young people."The past couple of weeks have shown what an amazing community we have in Peeblesshire, and through this resilience, perseverance and hard work we can all be very hopeful for the future of our school.Updates for Peebles High School can be found at www.scotborders.gov.uk phsfire

title: minister-champions-borders-distress-service
story: A SUPPORT team in the Borders have been commended by the countrys Minister for Mental Health.Clare Haughey MSP met with Borders DBI representatives in Galashiels last week to commend them in helping the national project win a prestigious Scottish Health Award.DBI provides an lsquoask once - get help fastrsquo early intervention for people in distress or emotional pain who do not need emergency medical treatment.After an inidualrsquos immediate distress is tackled, the person is askedthey would like further support andthey agree, they are referred to the DBI service with a promise of contact within the next  hours.Ms Haughey said: ldquoI want to congratulate the whole team on the fantastic work they do to support people who are experiencing signicant challenges in their lives.ldquoThis work supports our broad vision on mental health, of a Scotland where people can get the right help at the right time, expect recovery and fully enjoy their rights, free from discrimination and stigma.Data gathered so far shows on average, the level of distress of those who have received DBI support, has halved.Welcoming the minister to The Hive last week was Borders DBI programme manager Haylis Smith.She said: ldquoAlmost  people in the Borders have been supported to manage their distress since the pilot began.ldquoThe support given to these iniduals is the real reward for all of us, but we were delighted the Minister recognised the efforts of the arearsquos hospital emergency department, Police Scotland, Scottish Ambulance Service, primary care and third sector staff.The Scottish Government funded pilot picked up the Care for Mental Health award at the Scottish Health Awards in November.DBI programme manager Kevin OrsquoNeill, said: ldquoWe were delighted the Minister paid a visit to the Borders DBI team to hear and see for herself how their efforts are making a real dference to peoplersquos lives day in and day out.ldquoIt is the sensitivity of our staff to those in distress that inspires us all to work together to improve the outcomes and experiences of these people when they need help most.

title: celebrating-five-years-weight-loss-borders
story: FOR five years diet consultants Mark and Nicola Lafferty have been helping people in the Borders transform their lives and waistlines.This month, the couple scooped a long service recognition award in running their successful : diet consultancyrsquos, formerly known as the Cambridge Weight Plan, in Peebles and Galashiels.With Markrsquos training as an addictions therapist and Nicolarsquos mental health support background, the duo combined their skills, and pride themselves in taking an empathic approach in helping their clients achieve their goals.ldquoWe realise everyone is dferent and sometimes losing weight isnrsquot as straightforward as going on a diet, said Mark.ldquoWe help clients by looking into the reasons they gained weight in the first place and help them work on changing their mind-set to work more effectively, not only at losing the excess weight but in keeping it off too.They say the proof is in the pudding, which is true for the Laffertys who used their own dramatic weight loss with the diet to inspire others.Mark told us: ldquoI struggled with weight issues."As an addictions a counsellor I could help people with alcohol and drug dependency but I couldnrsquot manage my own weight.After embarking on the : diet and losing his excessive weight in a relatively short space of time, Mark wanted to help others.ldquoI knew it was worth setting up as a business to help people achieve their own weight loss goals, said Mark.Inspired by her husbandrsquos new slim physique, we Nicola decided to shed the pounds and embarked on her own : diet journey.For five years they have assisted many committed dieters to go from flab to fab and have also reported success with clients reversing type two diabetes.Mark said there are many weight loss journeys he and Nicola are proud to be a part of, adding: ldquoOne client lost four stone and turned his le around.And when a couple asked for their help to slim down to a healthy weight in order to undergo fertility treatment, the Laffertyrsquos stepped in and were delighted to hear the news that their clients are now expecting a baby.The dieting duo say they are overjoyed when clients step on the scales and achieve their target.ldquoItrsquos a great moment because we know how much it means to them. Seeing clients transform is so special. Itrsquos a privilege to be involved, said Mark.So how do the couple who helped hundreds of Tweeddale dieters slim down to their perfect weight plan to celebrate  The new delicious Cambridge festive bar Mark laughed: ldquoWe had a fantastic Christmas dinner at the ceremony. But I was good and didnrsquot eat the tatties!

title: volunteers-right-path
story: A NEW volunteers group has been launched in Peeblesshire to protect the popular multi-use paths.The Peeblesshire Paths Group will help look after the former railway line routes between Walkerburn and Peebles.And they will also take on shared responsibility for the upkeep of the soon-to-be-opened route between Peebles and Eddleston.The Peeblesshire Paths Group, which is affiliated to Peebles Community Trust, has been awarded a grant from Sustrans to help with buying equipment.And the group has also received backing from CycleLaw Scotland, Peebles Cycling Club, Tweedside Garden Machinery and CCA Signs.A spokesman for the new group told us: "All of this support has enabled us to purchase machinery and tools which are being stored with the help of Peebles Community Trust."We have also put up new signage in an effort to encourage potential volunteers to come forward."The initial section of the Tweed Valley Railway Path between Innerleithen and Peebles was opened in .Thousands of walkers, joggers, cyclists and horseriders use the old railway track bed every month.Earlier this year the pathway was extended to Walkerburn.Planning permission and funding has been granted to create a new path from Peebles all the way to Eddleston.And work is due to start in .The Peeblesshire Paths Group spokesman added: "Scottish Borders Council has responsibility for the paths in conjunction with our local volunteers who will help keep the pathways clear of litter, cut back vegetation and report any defects."The work is essential to help keep the pathways open and safe for use."We already have a base of volunteers who undertake regular work sessions twice per month."But we are always keen to recruit additional helpers, and all the tools, safety equipment and training are provided."If you like the outdoors and want a bit of exercise plus the satisfaction and enjoyment of helping to maintain this picturesque pathway which makes a dference to your community, then we would love you to join us."For further information on The Peeblesshire Paths Group email ppg@googlegroups

title: river-flames-welcome-new-decade
story: A TORCHLIGHT procession through Peebles more than doubled in size on Tuesday ahead of the bells.The already popular Hogmanay procession attracted more than , revellers this festive season.And all proceeds from the sale of the torches will go to support ongoing work at fire-ravaged Peebles High School as well as Peeblesshire Youth Trust.Event director Neil Dalgleish, from Hillside Outside, told us: ldquoIt was absolutely fantastic to bring together the community and visitors from near and far to welcome the new decade in our own Tweed Valley style."We wouldnrsquot want to spend Hogmanay any other way.The torchlight procession, which is held every two years, created a river of flames around the historic town.Starting on the towns High Street at .pm, the procession snaked its way gradually down to the banks of the Tweed.Visitors from across the UK and Europe were also treated to a head-of-procession piper and some traditional Highland dancing from students of the Fiona Henderson School of Dance.The event is organised by Hillside Outside in conjunction with partners Le Heal Peebles, Blackwood  Smith, Renwick and Weir, and Evolution Bottling and Packaging Solutions.Mr Dalgleish added: "It was great to bring together the community to welcome the new decade."

title: salsa-celtica-celebrations-come-galashiels-stage
story: LETS hope the Mac Arts stage is big enough when the worlds most exciting live band embark on their th anniversary year with a show in Galashiels.Salsa Celtica feature no fewer than  highly talented musicians hailing from Scotland, Ireland and Cuba.The bands incredible -year career includes creating their own unique style of music, winning awards, hit songs in Latin America and headlining at venues such as the Lincoln Centre in New York.And to celebrate the remarkable journey, which has taken them from the village halls of Scotland to some of the most prestigious venues and festivals around the globe, they are playing a celebration tour through the start of this year.And they will pull up at the Mac Arts on Friday, January  for a night not to be missed.A spokeswoman for the Mac Arts told us: "We are thrilled that Salsa Celtica are coming to Mac Arts as one of a few select dates to start off this celebratory year."Salsa Celticarsquos trademark synthesis of Latin American Salsa with Scottish and Irish traditional music has made them huge favourites on live circuits around the world.The combined depth of rhythm and melodies of salsa and Celtic make Salsa Celtica an irresistible force of passion, energy and joy.To mark this landmark th anniversary year, they will also be appearing at some favourite festivals later in the year, ing to play in Colombia, and will release two compilation albums spanning  years of recording.Tickets, priced at pound in advance, are available from the Mac Arts box office.All  members of Salsa Celtica will take to the Mac Arts stage from pm on Friday, January .

title: melrose-welcomes-2020-schubert
story: MUSIC lovers in Melrose are welcoming in the decade with one of Schubertrsquos most loved and poignant works.The acclaimed Fitzroy String Quartet will perform at the first Melrose Music Society concert of the s later this month.First violin Dan-Iulian Druta, who comes from Moldova, was Junior Guildhall Lutine Prize winner and makes regular appearances as a soloist with professional orchestras in the UK and mainland Europe. Laura Custodio Sabas from Catalonia, second violin, graduated from the Royal Academy of Music, where she was a member of an elite ensemble, has given chamber music recitals across the world and played with renowned professional orchestras.The viola player, Emily Pond, also graduated from the Royal Academy of Music after obtaining a first class BMusdegree at the RNCM in Manchester where she won the Viola Competition.As artist in residence in Italy in  , she gave recitals with leading European musicians and appeared with top European orchestras.Cellist Michael Newman obtained a Masters in Music degree with distinction at the Royal Academy of Music, also studied at the RNCM where he was a prize-winner for Romantic chamber music, and has performed widely as a soloist.On Saturday, January , collectively as the Fitzroy String Quartet they will perform Schubertrsquos D minor Quartet, D  .This four-movement piece derives its titlefrom the slow movement which is a set of iations on a theme from the composerrsquos song, Tod und das Maumldchen.The lyricism of this section of the quartet contrasts with the rhythmic energy of the opening movement and the ferocity and frenzy of the scherzo and the presto finale.The concert opens with a String Quartet in E flat major in three movements, by Boccherini, perhaps best known for the Minuet from his string quintet in E major, made famous in the  movie, The Ladykillers.This will be followed by Benedict Masonrsquos String Quartet No. . Composed in , it is a musical journey in five parts: perambulation, fast travelling, observing both standing still and travelling, and, finally, ing.The programme finishes with the Schubert quartet, written in  when the composer knew he was dying.Tickets, priced at pound and free for accompanied school-age children, will be available on the Melrose Parish Church Hall door.The concert is scheduled to start at .pm.

title: restoration-project-set-kick-off-iconic-stand
story: SCOTLANDrsquoS only A-listed football stand could be re-opened for the start of the new season following an encouraging structural report.Officials at Gala Fairydean Rovers have welcomed the findings of an intrusion survey carried out on their world-famous main stand.The Peter Womersley designed structure, which was built in , had shown signs of deterioration during last season.And following reports of crumbling masonry and cracking it was closed to football fans in November,  for safety reasons.A major structural survey was conducted during the summer and autumn with a finalised report being delivered just before Christmas.Ross Buchan, who is a quantity surveyor by trade, is leading the project for Gala Fairydean Rovers.The former player and committee member told us: ldquoThere was always the fear that the underlying problems would be signicant, but thankfully the primary enforcement of the stand is okay.ldquoWork is required on the secondary enforcement, and while that is still a big job, it is achievable.ldquoA good number of the repairs are ones that we foresaw andall goes well work could be completed by late summer.Womersleyrsquos late modernist stand is considered so culturally important that Historic Environment Scotland upgraded its status from B- to A-Listed in .The unique -capacity stand continues to attract architectural enthusiasts as well as football fans from across the globe.Although no firm timescale has yet been put on the estimated pound, repairs project, it is hoped to have a design team in place by March following a tendering process.And the works themselves could begin around June or July.Officials at the football club have already secured more than pound, in funding towards the project, and it is hoped once charitable status has been authorised further bids will be successful.Mr Buchan added: ldquoWe believe that the entire project will cost around pound,.ldquoWe will continue to submit funding applications andwe are still short closer to when work is due to begin we will lodge a crowdfunding appeal to hopefully make up any shortfall.ldquoThe next phase for us is to appoint a design team, consisting of an engineer, and architect and surveyor and a principal designer.Womersleyrsquos stand was officially opened on November ,  with a match between Gala Fairydean and East Fe.Officers from Scottish Borders Council, who conducted the investigation works, remain on the stands working group.A spokesperson for the local authority said: ldquoA comprehensive concrete investigation has now been completed and the findings have been reported back to Gala Fairydean Rovers Football Club."We will continue to provide advice to the club as it prepares the relevant tender documents for the restoration project in the new year."

title: spotify-superstar-benjamin-set-galashiels-gig
story: MORE than , follow him on Spoty and his songs have become soundtracks to many weddings, births and funerals in recent years.Benjamin Francis Leftwich made an instant impact in  with his debut album, Last Smoke Before The Snowstorm.And during the following years he has continued to produce melancholy masterpieces which have attracted plays in the millions across the most popular streaming services.Drawing comparisons to Damien Rice and Joseacute Gonzaacutelez, Leftwichs single Shine was named Spotys most addictive track of  as well as the most repeat-played song of the year.His second album, After the Rain, helped take the York-born singer to an even wider audience with tours across Canada, USA, China, Sweden, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, and throughout Asia.According to Spoty, Benjamin Francis Leftwich has an average ,, monthly listeners.And the release of last years album, Gratitude, will have done no harm at all to his streaming figures with another collection of beautul and soulful songs.Benjamin said: "Irsquove been really lucky over the past  years to have my music soundtrack really important events in peoplersquos lives, like weddings, funerals, births and probably break-ups as well ndash I get a fair few messages about that!"Itrsquos a privilege, and itrsquos humbling. title: pupils-buzzing-bee-research-day
story: BORDERS pupils are buzzing following a visit to the countrys leading research centre for protecting bees.Kelso High School is one of the growing number of secondaries in the country which have their own apiaries.And just before Christmas, along with student beekeepers from Annan Academy, pupils were given an insight into the work of Edinburgh Universitys purpose-built bee lab.During their day the Easter Bush Science Outreach Centre the pupils worked with researchers and experienced beekeepers from the Roslin Institute to understand how science can be used to monitor honey bee health.Dr Mark Barnett, a research fellow at the Roslin Institute, told us: "Itrsquos been such a wonderful experience working with the young people on this project and watching them engage with biology in a way that they can really connect with."Most of the pupils in this group do not study biological science and would not identy maths as a favourite subject either, so to hear them discuss DNA, parasites and probability so enthusiastically really goes to show the strength of this vocational qualication."Huge thanks to the highly professional Easter Bush Science Outreach Centre team who made the day so special for us all."Pests and diseases along with habitat loss, extreme weather and pesticides are blamed for the worrying decline in bee numbers across the country.And it is estimated that around one-third of the UKs population has been lost over the past decade.The pupils, who are enrolled in a new beekeeping course provided by the Scottish Qualications Authority, carried out experiments focused on two parasites that affect the health of bees.Prior to the lab visit they collected honey bee samples from their schoolsrsquo apiaries for DNA extraction.They observed parasites present in the bees by using molecular biology techniquesndash conducting PCR and DNA gel electrophoresis.And they were able to investigate parasites in their own bees.Kelso High teacher Ray Baxter told us: "Our students said that learning about DNA and new techniques in the lab was a fun, amazing experience ndash one of them actually said that the day at Easter Bush Science Outreach Centre was the best day she has ever had."The workshop enabled the pupils to develop a deeper understanding of the theory and techniques used in honey bee research.Thanks to this unique citizen science project, they now better understand the health of their bee colonies to better inform hive management.Fiona Highet, senior entomologist with the Scottish Government, added: "The success of this project has only been possible because people are committed to the idea of working in partnership to promote learning about honey bees."It is satisfying that learning science in the context of a fascinating topic such as honey bees can appeal to young people who have not previously shown an interest in these sciences."Spending a day at Easter Bush Science Outreach Centre was a unique opportunity for the pupils to engage with real-le science and Roslin Institute scientists, encouraging pupils to consider pursuing a science qualication and career."

title: bonmarche-close-doors-galashiels
story: BONMARCHEacute in Galashiels is set to close next week and joins the growing list of businesses leaving the towns high street.In , the womens clothing brand warned of losses as its share prices dropped by  per cent.During the summer Bonmarcheacute was bought out by Edinburgh Woollen Mill and Peacocks boss, Philip Day, in a pound.million rescue bid.This wasnt enough to save the business however, as bosses appointed administrators in October as the company couldnt meet its financial obligations.Last year Greggs moved its Channel Street shop to Market Street, leaving another empty unit, and Burton and Dorothy Perkins, both part of the Arcadia group, also closed.Councillor Euan Jardine, Executive Member for Culture  Sport, told us: "It is very disappointing news that these shops are closing."I have personally written to many established retailers in the hope that they see Galashiels as a viable option."Unfortunately, you cannot drag people into a vacant property but we need to try and promote Galashiels as somewhere worth investing."In many other aspects of the town centre, Scottish Borders Council alongside Energise Galashiels are being very proactive in trying to find other alternatives and resolutions for this issue."Businesses also need help from the Scottish Government in terms of rates relief. The internet has changed shopping forever so for our high streets to survive we need to re-evaluate how we operate to mitigate failure going forward."Despite requests for a response from Bonmarcheacute, no comment was given to the Border at the time of going to print.

title: a7-road-works-closure-scottish-water-works
story: MOTORISTS are advised that from Monday, January , the A at Selkirk, just south of Selkirk Golf Club, there will be road works in place.The works will last for five weeks and from tomorrowthe layby south of the GolfClub will be closed for the next  months.The works will allow Scottish Water to complete the laying of pipes across this section of the A.A traffic lights system in both directions will be in place.Scott Fraser, Regional Communities Manager at Scottish Water, said: ldquoWe apologise for any disruption this temporary road closure and use of traffic lights will cause.ldquoWe require this to carry out essential work as part of our pound million investment in the drinking water network in the Scottish Borders. We thank all commuters impacted by this in advance or their patience and understanding.A spokesperson from Scottish Water added: "This is part of a new -mile pipeline which will connect the Manse Street Water Treatment Works, situated to the west of Galashiels, to a new water storage tank in Selkirk."It will carry up to five million litres of treated water every day.#"Customers will not notice any interruption to their water supply as a result of this work as these are new pipes which are not yet in use."Adding to the road works along the A, the section of road will be closed from pm on Friday, January  until am on Monday, January  with ersions in place.For southbound traffic, motorists will leave A at Ladylands, Selkirk, turning left onto A - continue to A St Boswells Crossroads, turn right onto A, continue for approx. . miles to the A junction at Cleekimin, turn right onto A, continue along for approx. . miles to Hawick, at Mart Street Roundabout take rd exit onto Mart Street, continue along Mart Street to North Bridge Roundabout and re-join A.All northbound traffic will follow the same ersion in the opposite direction.

title: 28-year-old-admits-causing-bgh-disturbance
story: A HAWICK man who admitted causing a disturbance at Borders General Hospital at the weekend has been remanded in custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court.Twenty-eight-year-old William Devlin pleaded guilty to acting in an aggressive manner and shouting and swearing at the hospital on Sunday.He also admitted assaulting a police constable by throwing a cup of water at him, pushing him on the body and attempting to kick him.A not guilty plea to another charge of assaulting a police officer was accepted by the Crown.Sentence was deferred until January  when Devlin of Howdenbank, Hawick, has other matters calling.Sherf Andrew Webster said alcohol was a major reason for the offences and he noted bail aggravations.He added there was a risk of further offending so he refused a motion for bail and remanded him in custody until next Monday.Devlin was led from the dock protesting he was not the subject of any bail orders although he had appeared at Jedburgh Sherf Court and admitted breaching abail order on Boxing Day by being in a womans house in Allars Crescent, Hawick, from whom he was banned from having any contact with.He had been released on a second bail order on Friday, December .

title: mcdonalds-b-m-bargains-development-hawick-recommended-approval
story: PLANS for a drive-thru fast-food outlet and new supermarket in Hawick are being recommended for approval.But the development will still need the go-ahead from Government ministers due to flood fears for the Commercial Road site.The application by Image Estates for the retail and takeaway development last spring was widely welcomed in Hawick.The developers have been in talks with both McDonalds and BM Bargains to occupy the site.But ongoing concerns from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencywill mean that eventhe full application is accepted by members of Scottish Borders Council on Monday, final approval will rest at Holyrood.Despite assurances from bosses of the ongoing Hawick Flood Protection Scheme, SEPA has maintained its stance.Planning officer Stuart Herkes explained: "SEPA identies the sitersquos presence within the al flood plain, as the basis for its objection."Its concerns would be fully justied in any circumstance in which the proposed development were to go ahead without the Hawick Flood Protection Scheme first being in place."However, and despite the clear advice of the Hawick Flood Protection Scheme project team that it is able to directly accommodate the proposal within its calculations for the construction of the scheme, SEPA does not consider that it has been given sufficient reassurance that the site can be developed without unacceptable flood risk impacts."Owing to SEPArsquos outstanding objection in principle to this proposal on the grounds that the development would be at risk of, and would cause, unacceptable flooding impacts on the site and in the surrounding area, any approval of this application by members would itself require referral to, and approval by, Scottish Ministers."Image Estates hope to build the retail store as well as the restaurant with drive-thru facilities on the site of the former Bruce Motors showroom and neighbouring redundant mill buildings.During two public consultation events objections to the proposals were raised concerning flooding, the detriment of the environment and neighbouring amenities, as well as increased traffic the loss of historic buildings.But there has also been a lot of support for the plans.Mr Herkes added: "The area has been transformed into a commercial hub and is considered to be a welcome offshoot and support to the high street."Further, new developments are welcomedthey support new employment opportunities."The site appears able to accommodate the level of floor space shown and would likely encourage further footfall to this area, especially a new drive through hot food operation."

title: borders-clothing-charitys-bank-tie-continues-2020
story: A TIE-UP between a local clothing charity and Borders branches of the Royal Bank of Scotland has been so successful that bosses have opted to continue the partnership into the new year.In the run up to Christmas the Galashiels, Kelso and Peebles branches of the RBS acted as drop-off points for Tweed Togs.For the past three years the Tweeddale-based charity has been collecting good-quality childrens clothing.And, via referrals from health visitors, social workers and other organisations, has provided cleaned and ironed clothing packs for struggling families across the area.Dozens of items were left at the local banks every day in the run-up to Christmas.And now bosses at the local branches have decided to become permanent partners.Community banker for the Borders Amanda Baitup said: "Royal Bank of Scotland staff were delighted to be given the chance to help Tweed Togs."Most of our colleagues live locally and know the impact Tweed Togs make and staff across the business, including our colleagues at Lombard, were keen to get involved.ldquoWe were also so touched by the generosity of our customers.As well as using branches as collection points, staff from the RBS also spent an afternoon volunteering at the Tweed Togs depot.Amanda added: "It was an absolute pleasure to spend an afternoon working with Sandra, Jeanette and Sheena at Tweed Togs."Other drop-off points for Tweed Toggs include the Tontine Hotel, First Nursery and Fat Face in Peebles, Nashys Coffee House in Cardrona, the West Linton Early Learners Group, and the Co-op in Innerleithen.

title: children-frame-borders-art-fair-competition
story: BUDDING artists from across the Borders are being encouraged to dig out their brushes.The organisers of the Borders Art Fair have this week launched a special competition for primary school children.To mark Scotlandrsquos Year of Coasts and Waters, children aged from four up to are invited to send in artwork that celebrates the regionrsquos rivers, coastline and lochs.And the best entries will be displayed alongside work from some of the regionrsquos finest contemporary artists at this yearrsquos Borders Art Fair in March.Frances Fergusson, director of the Borders Art Fair, told us: ldquoThe Borders Art Fair is a great opportunity to see a huge selection of work by some incredible artists, in a friendly and welcoming environment."This region is home to many exceptionally talented artists and we hope that our programme of activities for young people will help to ensure that future talent is encouraged and nurtured."Maybe some of our budding young artists willto the Borders Art Fair in future years to show their work.The competition has two age categories - Primary - for four-to-eight year-olds, and Primary - for eight-to- year-olds - and prizes include a iety of art materials as well as pound of art supply vouchers for the schools or youth groups of the overall winners, kindly donated by the Arts Society Borders.The competition is part of the Borders Art Fairrsquos education outreach programme, which also includes a lsquoMeet the Creativesrsquo event for high school pupils.This will offer students the chance to hear from a range of people involved in creative jobs.A number of free, drop-in workshops and art sessions for children of all ages aimed at encouraging an interest in creativity will also be taking place at the Borders Art Fair.Frances added: "The  Borders Art Fair will feature around  artists, galleries and collectives in addition to artist-led talks and workshops."Visitors will have the chance to take advice from galleries, speak to the artists about their work and inspiration, and have the opportunity to purchase beautul and unique pieces of art."Information on entering the childrens competition will be sent to schools and youth groups this week.The deadline for receipt of entries is March .This years Borders Arts Fair takes place at Springwood Park near Kelso on the weekend of March  to .

title: tree-mendous-effort-gala-waterways-volunteers
story: THERE was no festive time off for Galas hardest-working volunteers last weekend.The Gala Waterways Group have been cleaning up the river bank for years.And last weekend a total of  volunteers yet again pulled on their gloves to tackle a stretch around the Skinworks Cauld.As well as collecting  kilogrammes of rubbish, which included a bicycle wheel, the group also coppiced trees, removed the prunings and installed one of the nest boxes recently donated by Galashiels Mens Shed.Sister Syphus from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in St George, Utah was among the volunteers.She said: "It was fun working with the wonderful people of Galashiels, making the town a cleaner place."The prunings taken during the morning filled a skip, which was placed on Low Buckholmside Road.David Usher, secretary of the Gala Waterways Group, added: "We are very grateful to all our volunteers for their hard work, and to Scottish Borders Council for providing a skip and dealing with the prunings."The next Gala Waterways Group workparty will be on Saturday, February .For more information contact David Usher on davidjusher@btinternet or  .

title: brass band to play national anthem at six nations rugby match
story: All  members of the senior band will perform before the Scotland v England women#s rugby match at Scotstoun Stadium on February , and again at Murrayfield Stadium before the men#s Six Nations Scotland v France match on March .Katrina told the Courier: #It is amazing but a bit scary # there will be , people in the stadium and it will be televised.#Campbeltown Brass was selected to perform the #potentially once-in-a-letime# Murrayfield gig after being recommended by Whitburn Band, Scotland#s national stadium#s resident brass band. Whitburn is unavailable on March  due to performing at the Scottish Championships, at which Campbeltown Brass will compete the day before.Despite the recommendation from one of the most successful bands in Scotland, Campbeltown Brass still had to go through an audition process, submitting sound recordings and video footage of performances, before finding out it was successful.To make sure the band is looking smart during the outdoor performances, Springbank Distillery has sponsored a full set of soft-shell jackets, emblazoned with the logos of both the band and the distillery.The jackets will be used at other outdoor events, besides the rugby, including remembrance services and while playing carols.In addition, the band has recently discovered that it is a finalist in the Argyll and Bute Youth Awards, which only take place once every three years, and members expect to find out in Februarythey are successful.The recent Christmas concert, at which Ranald Watson from Springbank Distillery officially presented the new jackets to the band, was described as #a great success#, and featured members of all Campbeltown Brass#s bands, from beginners, to intermediates and seniors.Held at the Kintyre Community Education Centre, the concert featured festive songs, as well as film hits and pop songs.#One that went down really well was the Schneewalzer,# Katrina said. #It#s a German snow waltz, which got the audience involved, standing up and sitting down, that kind of thing. And we played the  Days of Christmas, which is always good.#Katrina added: #Thank you to everyone for their continued support, especially parents of band members who take their children to practices every week.#Also to Tesco and the Coop for allowing us to play carols in the lead up to Christmas and to everyone who donated for their generosity.#

title: prestonpans-teenager-auditions-x-factor-band
story: In the new show, which began airing on Monday, Simon Cowell is searching for the next big British group.Louis Robertson, , of Nethershot Road, sang George Ezrarsquos Blame It On Me in a filmed audition in front of Simon Cowell, Nicole Scherzinger and a  of experts, one whom he recognised as the DJ Naughty Boy, at Sony Musicrsquos head office in London.Louis, who works at Scottish Widows, did not get through to the next stage of the competition but was delighted to have been picked to perform in front of the judges.He got a call on the Sunday night from the show producers after his mum and girlfriend filled in an application for him and sent off a video of him performing.The former Preston Lodge High School pupil said: ldquoI got a phone call askingI would like to go to an audition last Tuesday in London.ldquoI got time off my work and took the night bus down on the Monday night. I only had an hour of sleep on the way, so it was a dficult day.ldquoI did two auditions in front of producers and one in front of the judges in Simon Cowellrsquos office.ldquoSimon and Nicole were sitting judging at a table and then to the right of them was a  of experts, kind of like a jury that would comment on some contestants, not myself.ldquoI sang my first song and Simon stopped me and askedI had any original songs, which I do.ldquoI stood there for about five seconds panicking trying to think of something to sing!ldquoSo I sang one of my own ones but I didnrsquot have any backing tracks or anything so I had to do it a capella.ldquoIt was all filmed, itrsquos not a one hundred per cent guarantee that it will be on the telly so wersquoll just need to wait and see.ldquoThe sitting room outside his office was filmed as well and I had a little chat with [presenter] Dermot [OrsquoLeary] afterwards.ldquoI would have been buzzing to have got through obviously, but I donrsquot think the competition is really for me so Irsquom not that bothered.

title: historic-musselburgh-ice-cream-business-di-rollo-sale
story: The -year-old business has a shop on Bridge Street and ice cream factoryon South Street.But the owners of thebusiness, which was established in  and has been in the Di Rollo family ever since, will soon be retiring and are hoping that someone will take on the business.Independent Scottish chartered surveyorGraham + Sibbald is acting on behalf of theice cream manufacturer and wholesaler around the sale of the business.Di Rollo supplies a large selection of flavoured ice cream to many restaurants, cafes, hotels, catering companies and retail outlets across East Lothian and Edinburgh.The business includes a purpose-built production facility and the premises covers over , square feet.Graham + Sibbald say that the facility complies with all the latest EU directives and is capable of producing over  litres of ice cream an hour.Suzanne Lawrie, business valuer at Graham + Sibbald, said: ldquoDi Rollo Ice Cream is a much loved, successful regional business with a fantastic customer base."As a third-generation, family-run business, the current owners are planning their retirement and this underpins the decision to sell."We see this as an excellent opportunity to expand the business.

title: plans-rocket-engine-testing-site-turned
story: Skyroras bid to set up a base on the former coal handling plant at Port Seton had caused a ision between neighbouring community councils and saw nearly  objections lodged with East Lothian Council.And at a meeting of the local authoritys planning committee today , the proposal was rejected against the advice of council officials after planning convenor Councillor Norman Hampshire branded the development a "bad neighbour".Mr Hampshire told fellow committee members that he was concerned that allowing Skyrora to test rockets on the land, which is central to the councils future economic plans, could put other investors off.He said: "This is not a good neighbour ndash it is a bad neighbour development and my concern is this may deter potential investors from taking on development at the Cockenzie site."Skyrora had lodged an application to create a rocket engine testing site on the land, which is owned by the local authority, with plans to carry out five -second tests each month.But while they applied for temporary use of the site for five years, they told the planning committee they envisaged the possibility of not just expanding their presence in the community but potentially bringing a manufacturing facility, described as the size of an Ikea outlet, to Cockenzie.And while Prestonpans Community Council, which lies on the boundary of the site, supported their move as offering potential for jobs and the economy, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council objected.At the planning committee meeting this week, Bryan Hickman, from Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council, pointed to a public meeting which had seen between  and  people turn out.He said: "Virtually everyone who was there was against it ranging from our youngest residents to pensioners. The feeling, rightly or wrongly, in the community is that they do not want it."During the planning meeting local residents raised concerns about the storage of key elements of fuel on the site for days prior to testing as well as the impact of burning kerosene into the atmosphere.While Skyrora insisted the engine tests would be a "clean burn" producing mainly water, resident and biochemist Dr Brian Hall told the committee that he estimated around , litres of carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide could be released during each  second test.Calum Miller, on behalf of Prestonpans Community Council, urged councillors to approve the plans pointing out that the power station site had lain empty now for six years.He told them: "The council has the opportunity with this Skyrora application to dispel the myth that we are too remote from Edinburgh to attract business."However ward councillors Fiona ODonnell, Lachlan Bruce and Neil Gilbert all refused to vote in favour of planning approval.Councillor ODonnell said that the impact on local amenity would be unacceptable and spoke of the "high level of public concern" from constituents about the proximity of the test site to housing ndash the nearest of which was estimated at  metres away.The plans were rejected by six councillors to two.

title: tranent-youngster-selling-reindeer-food-good-cause
story: Archie Lusk, eight, of Meetinghouse Drive, decided he wanted to raise money to help the homeless this Christmas, so opted to make reindeer food to sell rather than spend money on Christmas cards.The reindeer food, made by the P Ormiston Primary School pupil, is a mix of oats and other special ingredients.It is packaged with a label that reads: ldquoSprinkle on the lawn at night, the moon will make it sparkle bright, as Santarsquos reindeers fly and roam, this will guide them to your home.Archie has already raised pound.
